qas.question: Was CBC one of the first or last stations to adopt a 24 hour schedule?
When did stations previously sign off the air?

answers.text: early morning hours (typically from 1:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m.)

qas.question: What did private stations air when programming was not ticketed?
What does CBC use unallotted airtime for?

answers.text: local news, primetime series, movies and other programming from the CBC library

qas.question: Which French station has refused to adopt a 24 hour schedule?
When did the CBC begin to air programming on their network?
What time period did the FCC once require broadcasters to sign off the air?

plausible_answers.text: repeats, including local news, primetime series, movies and other programming

qas.question: Polls show that viewers prefer when 24 hour stations air what type of content?
What popular news network was CBC News Network inspired by?
Which French news station is CBC News greatest competitor?

context: On <b5_0>October 9, 2006 at 6:00 a.m.<b5_0/>, the network switched to a 24-hour schedule, becoming one of the <a0_0>last<a0_0/> major English-language broadcasters to transition to such a schedule. Most CBC-owned stations previously signed off the air during the <a1_0>early morning hours (typically from <b6_0>1:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m<b6_0/>.)<a1_0/>. Instead of the <a2_0>infomercials<a2_0/> aired by most private stations, or a simulcast of CBC News Network in the style of BBC One's nightly simulcast of <b8_0>BBC<b8_0/> News Channel, the CBC uses the time to air <b7_0>repeats, including <a3_0>local news, primetime series, movies and other programming<b7_0/> from the CBC library<a3_0/>. Its French counterpart, <a4_0><b9_0>Ici Radio-Canada Télé<b9_0/><a4_0/>, still signs off every night.
